text: This aimed at GPS users - I was watching the first Yarmouth race in my render software and the final suspension inplay occurred when my stuff clocked an eighth of a furlong left to go. Of course this could be errors in my stuff or betfair being trigger happy with early suspend, but just a word of warning to anyone using GPS. Unfortunately I cannot check the lag times easily at present but if the same happens in the next I will be killing my GPS bot for the rest of the day. Any confirmation of this from other users would be very welcome

attachments.title: Ep: 107 - CEO of Total Performance Data by Business of Betting PODCAST
attachments.text:
Episode 107 - Will Duff Gordon  

Will joins the podcast to talk about his business  and the use of tracking technology and data for betting and performance evaluation. 

Season 5 is proudly sponsored by Betfair Pty Limited. Betfair operates a betting exchange and is licensed in the Northern Territory, Australia. Join by clicking here:  and entering code BOBPOD. 
The Betfair exchange isn’t a house that sets the odds, it’s betting at it’s purest. One punters opinion against another’s. Play the game within the game and join today.

text: I'm late to the party as usual. Interesting reading about the GPS feeds, I didn't even know they existed! To the professionals among us: would you say that 3rd party data sources are essential nowadays or can decent profits be made from simple strategies based on nothing but the Betfair API data?

elements.text: I'm late to the party as usual. Interesting reading about the GPS feeds, I didn't even know they existed! To the professionals among us: would you say that 3rd party data sources are essential nowadays or can decent profits be made from simple strategies based on nothing but the Betfair API data?

text: Can be done either way. Certainly not essential.

elements.text: Can be done either way. Certainly not essential.

text: I think if you can tie a good understanding of market dynamics together with superior data that's the ideal.

text:
<@UBS7QANF3> <@UGV299K6H> I've been running various reincarnations of 15+ year old "value" strategies for....15+ years. All simple mathematical strategies that earn pocket money rather than a salary. I took the decision to distance myself from studying form, sport stats, etc about 10 years ago because my conclusion was that those are already built into the betfair prices/bookie odds and are being compiled by sophisticated learning algorithms. I've never had enough time or intelligence to get into the depths of machine learning to a level where I would be competitive.
TBH, I'm now very surprised that I make any profit at all with my dumb "if...if...if...bet...goto next market" type strategies!

elements.text:
I've been running various reincarnations of 15+ year old "value" strategies for....15+ years. All simple mathematical strategies that earn pocket money rather than a salary. I took the decision to distance myself from studying form, sport stats, etc about 10 years ago because my conclusion was that those are already built into the betfair prices/bookie odds and are being compiled by sophisticated learning algorithms. I've never had enough time or intelligence to get into the depths of machine learning to a level where I would be competitive.
TBH, I'm now very surprised that I make any profit at all with my dumb "if...if...if...bet...goto next market" type strategies!

text: <@U016GUPM2UR> Totally agree with <@UBS7QANF3>. 20 bets is nowhere near meaningful. You could achieve similar or better results with a completely random strategy. Personally, I don't even check my P&L until 1000+ markets and even then, I'm fully aware that it could all go pear-shaped with a handful of "unlucky" bets. In particular, watch out for the bigger wins as they can make a massive difference to the ROI. For example, if you were backing 100/1 shots and the first bet won, you'd have a massive ROI initially but it's highly likely that the next 99 will lose...leaving the strategy -EV after commission.

elements.text: Totally agree with

. 20 bets is nowhere near meaningful. You could achieve similar or better results with a completely random strategy. Personally, I don't even check my P&L until 1000+ markets and even then, I'm fully aware that it could all go pear-shaped with a handful of "unlucky" bets. In particular, watch out for the bigger wins as they can make a massive difference to the ROI. For example, if you were backing 100/1 shots and the first bet won, you'd have a massive ROI initially but it's highly likely that the next 99 will lose...leaving the strategy -EV after commission.

text: It might (stress '*might'*) be that you're profiting for reasons other than what you planned. If it's just pocket money from small bets then you could just be taking a little noise or the spread. There's nothing wrong with that - if you can understand where your profits come from then you can expand them. There have been a couple of people who wrote honest looking blogs about making small profits from automation (like <http://machinebetting.com|machinebetting.com>). It strikes me that these people don't understand why they're making money and that's why they stall or fail when they try to scale. machinebetting is a classic example of someone overlooking the blindingly obvious, failing to connect the idea that small stakes were an essential element of his success and being baffled when increasing his volume decreased his profits. If he'd managed to put that together and understand the reasons he might still be blogging now.
